fields.Translation: (English) Good morning, I'm Jacom  (Jacopo in Italian) e I'm a Lombard student. Even if it is strange to say, since normally this language is not learnt at school, often it's only called "dialect" by the most, or maybe by almost everybody. And it's sad to see such a linguistic heritage forgotten e left dying because it hasn't the same istitutional recognition of other languages. I'm not a native speaker, as I've already said, but I'm always been in contact with my grandparents that know it. So the typical sounds of Lombard, such as "u" ([y]) e "≈ì" ([≈ì]), are natural to me, but I feel like I miss some words e the grammar. Nevertheless, I started studying the language on my own as much as I could and I think I've reached a good level. I started speaking with people from all over Lombardy, but also from outside, like for example some from Ticino or Trentino, because I was born and I've always lived in Milan. I've always been keen on linguistics and on the Milanese dialect and when I discovered the Lombard's condition, these two passions were brought togheter. Its condition is really bad: in the biggest cities it is never spoken, grandparents pass not on the language to their children nor to their grandchildren, and if they do it, the language is kept in family private contexts. I believe that losing a language is losing a different view of the world, a more particular view on reality. I would like to teach the language to my children in the future, but with Italian. That's beacause of the cultural heritage behind them, the bilinguism benefits and also because, all in all, I'm a native speaker of Italian e Italian is the language I feel more close to, with Lombard as well. Then I think that is important that the Lombard language is spoken. Because it's useful to write popular poems and songs, but it is necessary that the language is alive at home, in the streets and that it's passed on by fathers. I hope, then, I will hear it again all over Lombardy, as it was spoken in the past.  That's all, I thank Wikitongues for the possibility it gives to endangered languages to have a voice on the Internet. Bye!
